dataIdInfo.idAbs: Given a set of raster data and user optimal values, the Land Suitability tool determines the most suitable place to carry out an activity. In agriculture, it could be used to identify places with the best biophysical and socioeconomic conditions for a certain crop to do well.
dataIdInfo.idCredit: International Center for Tropical Agriculture - CIAT | Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation - CSIRO

tool.name: LandSuitability
tool.parameters:
A table with raster data that contains values that will be used to perform suitability analysis . The following field values are required:

  • Min Value — An editable field that initially has the input raster minimum value. ONLY integer and float values are allowed in this field.

  • Optimal From — This is an editable field that can ONLY accept float and integer values. The value entered should be greater than the Min Value and less than the Optimal To value.

  • Optimal To — This is an editable field that can ONLY accept float and integer values. The value entered should be greater than the Optimal From value and less than Max Value.

  • Max Value — An editable field that initially has the input raster maximum value. ONLY integer and float values are allowed in this field.

  • Combine-Yes/No — Denotes whether a raster input will be combined with another raster in the table during the analysis ideally because together they posses similar influence on the suitability of a location. The following options are allowed as entries:

    • No— This is the default value meaning the current input raster will NOT be combined with others during analysis.

    • Yes— Using this option, the current input raster will be combined with other inputs.

NOTE: The decision to combine input raster datasets should take a top-down approach. For example, if the preceding Combine-Yes/No field value is No and the succeeding is Yes, this two inputs will be combined together. More than two input raster datasets can be combined together starting with a No field value entry followed by a Yesentry on the rest of the inputs.

A table with raster data that contains values that will be used to perform suitability analysis . The following field values are required:

  • Min Value — An editable field that initially has the input raster minimum value. ONLY integer and float values are allowed in this field.

  • Optimal From — This is an editable field that can ONLY accept float and integer values. The value entered should be greater than the Min Value and less than the Optimal To value.

  • Optimal To — This is an editable field that can ONLY accept float and integer values. The value entered should be greater than the Optimal From value and less than Max Value.

  • Max Value — An editable field that initially has the input raster maximum value. ONLY integer and float values are allowed in this field.

  • Combine-Yes/No — Denotes whether a raster input will be combined with another raster in the table during the analysis ideally because together they posses similar influence on the suitability of a location. The following options are allowed as entries:

    • No— This is the default value meaning the current input raster will NOT be combined with others during analysis.

    • Yes— Using this option, the current input raster will be combined with other inputs.

NOTE: The decision to combine input raster datasets should take a top-down approach. For example, if the preceding Combine-Yes/No field value is No and the succeeding is Yes, this two inputs will be combined together. More than two input raster datasets can be combined together starting with a No field value entry followed by a Yesentry on the rest of the inputs.

Combine-Yes/No — Denotes whether a raster input will be combined with another raster in the table during the analysis ideally because together they posses similar influence on the suitability of a location. The following options are allowed as entries:

  • No— This is the default value meaning the current input raster will NOT be combined with others during analysis.

  • Yes— Using this option, the current input raster will be combined with other inputs.

NOTE: The decision to combine input raster datasets should take a top-down approach. For example, if the preceding Combine-Yes/No field value is No and the succeeding is Yes, this two inputs will be combined together. More than two input raster datasets can be combined together starting with a No field value entry followed by a Yesentry on the rest of the inputs.

Input feature class that defines the extent of processing.

Input feature class that defines processing extent.

Output raster showing suitable areas

Output raster showing suitable areas
tool.summary: Given a set of raster data and user optimal values, the Land Suitability tool determines the most suitable place to carry out an activity. In agriculture, it could be used to identify places with the best biophysical and socioeconomic conditions for a certain crop to do well.
tool.usage:
• This tool expects raster input capturing various biophysical and socioeconomic factors that influences choice of location in implementing a planned activity. For example in choosing the best place that a certain crop would do well, one would consider factors such as; elevation, slope, temperature, soils, population, access to markets etc.

  • To produce relatively accurate results in land suitability analysis, it is expected that the user knows the necessary/optimal conditions for a certain phenomena to occur or do better. Therefore the Land Suitability tool optimal range values (Optimal From - Optimal To) should be entered to produce an output.

  • The Optimal From value entry can be less than the Min Value but not greater than the Optimal To value. On the other hand, the Optimal To value is not allowed to be greater than the Max Value and not less than the Optimal From value.

  • Min Value and Max Value fields are editable with the default values automatically generated from raster data.

  • A times, there are some biophysical and socioeconomic factors that have similar influences on a phenomena or productivity of land and as a user of this tool you would want to process them together. The Combine-Yes/No field entry (Yes or No) facilitates this by processing two or more raster datasets as a block to produce an intermediate output or even better, a land suitability output.

  • Processing can also be restricted to a small area by loading a polygon into the Output extent parameter.

  • The output of this tool is a raster file with continuous cell values ranging between 0 to 1. A cell with a value of 1 indicates the most suitable location for a certain phenomena to occur or do better. Suitability or potential of a location to produce reduces drastically as you move from higher cell values (starting from 1) to lower cell values (ending at 0).
